title: Predicting drug-target interactions from chemical and genomic kernels using Bayesian matrix factorization

author: Mehmet Gönen, Department of Information and Computer Science, Aalto University

segmentation: This is the outline.
For my talk first I will introduce the problem and give the motivation.
Then I will describe the materials that we used for the.
Algorithim and I will briefly describe earlier approaches earlier machine learning approaches than I will describe.
Our method then I will conclude with results on some future work.
OK, why do we want to estimate drug target predict interactions?
Because we can modulate functions of the proteins using drugs and we have two information sources.
We have a growing knowledge of chemical space of drugs and genomic space of proteins due to high throughput screening assays and also high throughput genomic projects.
But the problem is that we have a limited knowledge about relationship between these two spaces.
And This is why we need some computational methods for this prediction problem.
And also another problem is that we have some existing databases, but these databases only contains contain experimentally validated interactions.
And of course these are.
These contain missing interactions and that's why we need computational methods for identifying interactions, and this will bring 2 advantages.
First, we can guide biologists towards new predictions, or we can provide supporting evidence for their experimental results.
OK, basically traditional approaches can be categorized into three main groups.

First one is knocking simulations, but this hasn't disadvantage of structural information requirements and for some protein families we don't have these in formation and that's why this is not applicable to all proteins.
And the second category is ligand based approaches and is in this approach we have to have a significant number of.
The interactions for each target protein and this may not be possible for all proteins, and the third one literature takes mining an.
In this approach we can only predict interactions that are.
Validated in biological publications and the other thing is other problem for this approach is that most of the time they use different naming practices.
So it is very hard to mine these textual data.
And that's why we have machine learning methods for this problem, and we have three input sources, input data sources for these algorithms.
The first one is chemical properties of drugs and the second one is genomic properties of target proteins, and we also have a partial knowledge about the interaction network.
We only know experimentally validated interactions.
And most of the machine learning algorithms have these underlying hypothesis.

Similar drug compounds are likely to interact with similar target proteins, and I underline these similar words because these similarities can be encoded using kernel functions because kernel functions mean they solve formulating similarities.
And if you have two kernel functions, one of them for drugs and one of the other one is for.
Proteins we can easily model the similarities.
OK, in this Saturday we used four important protein families.
These are enzymes, ion channels G protein coupled receptors are nuclear receptors.

These four protein families are particularly particularly important because they are mostly related to diseases and we will solve these interaction prediction problem for these four important families.
And we used for data sets from an earlier study and.
The largest one is enzyme data set, and it contains more than 400 trucks and more than 600 proteins and smallest one is nuclear receptors.
It contains 54 drugs and 26 proteins and if you look at the number of interactions it changed with the database.
But if you look at the ratio of interactions ratio of the experimental validated interactions to the total possible number of interactions, we see that.
Enzyme data set has possibly quote more than quarter million interactions and we only know 3000 of them.
An it corresponds to around 1% and for the nickel receptors, the experimental validates the interactions amount to almost 7%, and as you can see, these interaction networks are very sparse.
OK.

The first one is drugs and for the drugs we have very basic similarity function which is called SIM comp and it basically represents the drugs.

As graphs and we had a fixed set of substructures, we have fixed Dictionary of substructures and they look for these substructures in each track and at the end we can represent each track as a binary vector, whether each at each position we have binary values.
Whether these substructure exist in this drug or not and at the end we can have two binary vectors.
When we are calculating the similarity between two drugs.
And the similarity between two dots is the number of the ratio of common substructures.
Basically this similarity gives us score between zero and one.
And of course the similarity between the same drugs, the similarity.
Is equal to 1 an if they don't have any common substructure, the similarity will be 0.

We have target proteins and again we are using second space similarity because sequence space similarity can be calculated for each protein family.

The first one is we want to be able to.
Do out of sample predictions.
For example, if you are given a new drug, we want to estimate the interacting proteins from the training data.
Or if you are given a new target protein, we want to estimate interacting tracks from the training data.
Or the hardest problem is that we are given a new drug and then you target protein which are not seen during trainings and we want to estimate the interaction.
Or between these two objects, this is the hardest case, of course.

Out of these three and second prediction problem is that we want to complete this given interaction in network because we only know the experimentally validated interactions which may not be complete and we want to fill this matrix.
